This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. ILINK requests that means (and confidence limits) are displayed on the inverse linked scale. JOIN | CONNECT connects the least squares means with lines. This option is implied by the CLBAND option. SLICEBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to group the means in a single plot. PLOTBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to break interaction plots into separate displays.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the seed for the sampling-based components of the computations for the LSMEANS statement (for example, chi-bar-square statistics and simulated p-values). number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random-number generator for the simulation. If you do not specify a seed, or if you specify a value less than or equal to zero, the seed is generated from reading the time of day from the computer clock.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking. The value for number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 1E-4.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN=
arguments.description: Requests that multiple comparison adjustments for the p-values of LS-mean differences be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. Step-down methods increase the power of multiple comparisons by taking advantage of the fact that a p-value is never declared significant unless all smaller p-values are also declared significant. You can specify the following step-down options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment should be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

statements.name: LSMESTIMATE
statements.description: The LSMESTIMATE statement provides a mechanism for obtaining custom hypothesis tests among least squares means.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across estimates.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the LS-mean estimates. The adjusted quantities are produced in addition to the unadjusted p-values and confidence limits. Adjusted confidence limits are produced if the CL or ALPHA= option is in effect.

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. SEED=number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation. THREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be divided into parallel threads, where the number of threads is the value of the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=. NOTHREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be performed in sequence rather than in parallel. NOTHREADS is the default. This option overrides the SAS system option THREADS|NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: T
arguments.description: The default, which really signifies no adjustment for multiple comparisons.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means with confidence level 1-number. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Modifies the values of the covariates used in computing LS-means. By default, all covariate effects are set equal to their mean values for computation of standard LS-means. The AT option enables you to assign arbitrary values to the covariates. Additional columns in the output table indicate the values of the covariates.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that the procedure compute separate margins for each level of the LSMEANS effect.

arguments.name: CATEGORY=
arguments.description: Specifies how to construct estimates and multiplicity corrections for models with multinomial data (ordinal or nominal). This option is also important for constructing sets of estimable functions for F tests with the JOINT option.

arguments.name: JOINT
arguments.description: Computes the estimable functions for every nonredundant category and treats them as a set. For example, a three-row LSESTIMATE statement in a model with three response categories leads to six estimable functions.

arguments.name: SEPARATE
arguments.description: Computes the estimable functions for every nonredundant category in turn. For example, a three-row LSESTIMATE statement in a model with three response categories leads to two sets of three estimable functions.

arguments.name: quoted-value-list
arguments.description: Computes the estimable functions only for the list of values given. The list must consist of formatted values of the response categories.

arguments.name: CHISQ
arguments.description: Requests that chi-square tests be performed in addition to F tests, when you request an F test with the JOINT option. This option has no effect in procedures that produce chi-square statistics by default.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means. The confidence level is 0.95 by default; this can be changed with the ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the linear combination of the least squares means.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the linear combination of the least squares means.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIVISOR=
arguments.description: Specifies a list of values by which to divide the coefficients so that fractional coefficients can be entered as integer numerators. If you do not specify value-list, a default value of 1.0 is assumed. Missing values in the value-list are converted to 1.0.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L coefficients of the estimable function be displayed.

arguments.name: ELSM
arguments.description: Requests that the K matrix coefficients be displayed. These are the coefficients that apply to the LS-means. This option is useful to ensure that you assigned the coefficients correctly to the LS-means.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Requests exponentiation of the least squares means estimate. When you model data with the logit link function and the estimate represents a log odds ratio, the EXP option produces an odds ratio. If you specify the CL or ALPHA= option, the (adjusted) confidence limits for the estimate are also exponentiated.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that the estimate and its standard error are also reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: JOINT=
arguments.description: Requests that a joint F or chi-square test be produced for the rows of the estimate. You can specify the following joint-test-options in parentheses: ACC=γ specifies the accuracy radius for determining the necessary sample size in the simulation-based approach of Silvapulle and Sen (2004) for tests with order restrictions. The value of γ must be strictly between 0 and 1; the default value is 0.005. EPS=є specifies the accuracy confidence level for determining the necessary sample size in the simulation-based approach of Silvapulle and Sen (2004) for tests with order restrictions. The value of є must be strictly between 0 and 1; the default value is 0.01. LABEL='label' assigns an identifying label to the joint test. If you do not specify a label, the first non-default label for the ESTIMATE rows is used to label the joint test. NOEST | ONLY performs only the F or chi-square test and suppresses other results from the ESTIMATE statement. This option is useful for emulating the CONTRAST statement that is available in other procedures. NSAMP=n specifies the number of samples for the simulation-based method of Silvapulle and Sen (2004). CHISQ -- adds a chi-square test if the procedure produces an F test by default.
arguments.help: JOINT=ACC= | EPS= | LABEL= | NOEST | ONLY | NSAMP= | CHISQ | BOUNDS=

arguments.name: LOWER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values less than the test statistic. A two-tailed test is the default. A lower-tailed confidence limit is also produced if you specify the CL or ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS=
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients. The standard LS-means have equal coefficients across classification effects; however, the OM option changes these coefficients to be proportional to those found in the OM-data-set. This adjustment is reasonable when you want your inferences to apply to a population that is not necessarily balanced but has the margins observed in OM-data-set.

arguments.name: PLOTS=
arguments.description: Produces ODS statistical graphics of the distribution of estimable functions if the procedure performs the analysis in a sampling-based mode.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this LSMEANS statement be produced.

arguments.name: BOXPLOT
arguments.description: Produces box plots of the distribution of the least squares mean or least squares mean differences across a posterior sample. For example, this plot is available in procedures that support a Bayesian analysis through the BAYES statement. A separate box is generated for each estimable function, and all boxes appear on a single graph by default. You can affect the appearance of the box plot graph with the following options: ORIENTATION=VERTICAL|HORIZONTAL ORIENT=VERT|HORIZ specifies the orientation of the boxes. The default is vertical orientation of the box plots. NPANELPOS=number specifies how to break the series of box plots across multiple panels. If the NPANELPOS option is not specified, or if number equals zero, then all box plots are displayed in a single graph; this is the default.

arguments.name: DISTPLOT
arguments.description: Generates panels of histograms with a kernel density overlaid if the analysis has access to a set of posterior parameter estimates. You can sepcify the following distplot-options in parentheses: BOX|NOBOX controls the display of a horizontal box plot of the estimable function's distribution across the posterior sample below the graph. The BOX option is enabled by default. HIST|NOHIST controls the display of the histogram of the estimable function's distribution across the posterior sample. The HIST option is enabled by default. NORMAL|NONORMAL controls the display of a normal density estimate on the graph. The NONORMAL option is enabled by default. KERNEL|NOKERNEL controls the display of a kernel density estimate on the graph. The KERNEL option is enabled by default. NROWS=number specifies the highest number of rows in a panel. The default is 3. NCOLS=number specifies the highest number of columns in a panel. The default is 3. UNPACK unpacks the panel into separate graphics.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking as documented for the ESTIMATE statement.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN=
arguments.description: Requests that multiplicity adjustments for the p-values of estimates be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. Step-down methods increase the power of multiple testing procedures by taking advantage of the fact that a p-value is never declared significant unless all smaller p-values are also declared significant. You can specify the following step-down-options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. The default is MAXTIME=60. ORDER=PVALUE ORDER=ROWS specifies the order in which the step-down tests are performed. ORDER=PVALUE is the default, with LS-mean estimates being declared significant only if all LS-mean estimates with smaller (unadjusted) p-values are significant. If you specify ORDER=ROWS, then significances are evaluated in the order in which they are specified. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

arguments.name: TESTVALUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the value under the null hypothesis for testing the estimable functions in the LSMESTIMATE statement. The rules for specifying the value-list are very similar to those for specifying the divisor list in the DIVISOR= option. If no TESTVALUE= is specified, all tests are performed as H: Lβ=0. Missing values in the value-list also are translated to zeros. If you specify fewer values than rows in the ESTIMATE statement, the last value in value-list is carried forward. The TESTVALUE= option affects only p-values from individual, joint, and multiplicity-adjusted tests. It does not affect confidence intervals.

arguments.name: UPPER
arguments.description: Requests that the p-value for the t test be based only on values greater than the test statistic. A two-tailed test is the default. An upper-tailed confidence limit is also produced if you specify the CL or ALPHA= option.

statements.name: MODEL
statements.description: <label:> MODEL variable<(variable_options)>=<effects></ options> ; The MODEL statement names the response variable and the explanatory effects, including covariates, main effects, interactions, and nested effects.

arguments.name: DESCENDING
arguments.description: [response variable option] Reverses the order of the response categories.

arguments.name: EVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the event category for the binary response model.

arguments.name: 'category'
arguments.description: Replace 'category' with an actual event category.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered category as the event.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered category as the event. This is the default.

arguments.name: ORDER=
arguments.description: [response variable option] Specifies the sort order for the levels of the response variable.

arguments.name: DATA
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the order of appearance in the input data set.

arguments.name: FORMATTED
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the external formatted value, except for numeric variables with no explicit format, which are sorted by their unformatted (internal) value.

arguments.name: FREQ
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the descending frequency count; levels with the most observations come first in the order.

arguments.name: INTERNAL
arguments.description: Levels are sorted by the unformatted value.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: [response variable option] Specifies the reference category for the generalized logit model and the binary response model.

arguments.name: 'category'
arguments.description: Replace <'category'> with an actual value (formatted if a format is applied) of the event category in quotes.

arguments.name: FIRST
arguments.description: Designates the first ordered category as the reference category.

arguments.name: LAST
arguments.description: Designates the last ordered category as the reference category. This is the default.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: AGGREGATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the subpopulations on which the Pearson chi-square test statistic and the likelihood ratio chi-square test statistic (deviance) are calculated.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Sets the level of significance, a, for 100(1 - α)% confidence intervals for regression parameters or odds ratios. The value of number must be between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: BEST=
arguments.description: Specifies that n models with the highest score chi-square statistics are to be displayed for each model size.

arguments.name: BINWIDTH=
arguments.description: Specifies the size of the bins used for estimating the association statistics.

arguments.name: CLODDS=
arguments.description: Produces confidence intervals for odds ratios of main effects not involved in interactions or nestings.

arguments.name: PL
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on the profile likelihood (CLODDS=PL)

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on the individual Wald tests (CLODDS=WALD).

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on both the profile likelihood and individual Wald tests

arguments.name: CLPARM=
arguments.description: Requests confidence intervals for the parameters.

arguments.name: PL
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on the profile likelihood (CLODDS=PL)

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on the individual Wald tests (CLODDS=WALD).

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Computation of confidence intervals is based on both the profile likelihood and individual Wald tests

arguments.name: CORRB
arguments.description: Displays the correlation matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: COVB
arguments.description: Displays the covariance matrix of the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: CTABLE
arguments.description: Classifies the input binary response observations according to whether the predicted event probabilities are above or below some cutpoint value z in the range (0,1).

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: Produces a summary of computational details for each step of the effect selection process.

arguments.name: EQUALSLOPES
arguments.description: Specifies one or more effects that have the same parameters for each response function in a polytomous response model. If you specify more than one effect, enclose the effects in parentheses. The effects must be explanatory effects that are specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: EXPB
arguments.description: Displays the exponentiated values of the parameter estimates Bi in the "Analysis of Maximum Likelihood Estimates" table for the logit model.

arguments.name: FAST
arguments.description: Uses a computational algorithm of Lawless and Singhal (1978) to compute a first-order approximation to the remaining slope estimates for each subsequent elimination of a variable from the model.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FIRTH
arguments.description: Performs Firth's penalized maximum likelihood estimation to reduce bias in the parameter estimates.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: HIERARCHY=
arguments.description: Specifies whether and how the model hierarchy requirement is applied and whether a single effect or multiple effects are allowed to enter or leave the model in one step.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Indicates that the model hierarchy is not maintained.

arguments.name: SINGLE
arguments.description: Indicates that only one effect can enter or leave the model at one time, subject to the model hierarchy requirement.

arguments.name: SINGLECLASS
arguments.description: Is the same as HIERARCHY=SINGLE except that only CLASS effects are subject to the hierarchy requirement.

arguments.name: MULTIPLE
arguments.description: Indicates that more than one effect can enter or leave the model at one time

arguments.name: MULTIPLECLASS
arguments.description: Is the same as HIERARCHY=MULTIPLE except that only CLASS effects are subject to the hierarchy requirement.

arguments.name: INCLUDE=
arguments.description: Specifies effects in the MODEL statement to include in every model during model selection. You can specify the following values:

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Requests that the first number effects be included in every model.

arguments.name: EQUALSLOPES
arguments.description: Enables you to include all the equal slope effects in every model and perform the selection process on the unequal slope effects.

arguments.name: INFLUENCE=
arguments.description: Displays diagnostic measures for identifying influential observations in the case of a binary response model. For each observation, the INFLUENCE option displays the case number (which is the sequence number of the observation), the values of the explanatory variables included in the final model, and the regression diagnostic measures developed by Pregibon (1981).

arguments.name: IPLOTS
arguments.description: Produces an index plot for each regression diagnostic statistic. An index plot is a scatter plot with the regression diagnostic statistic represented on the Y axis and the case number on the X axis.

arguments.name: ITPRINT
arguments.description: Displays the iteration history of the maximum-likelihood model fitting.

arguments.name: LACKFIT
arguments.description: Performs the Hosmer and Lemeshow goodness-of-fit test for the case of a binary response model. The subjects are divided into approximately 10 groups of roughly the same size based on the percentiles of the estimated probabilities. The discrepancies between the observed and expected number of observations in these groups are summarized by the Pearson chi-square statistic, which is then compared to a chi-square distribution with t degrees of freedom, where t is the number of groups minus n. By default, n=2. A small p-value suggests that the fitted model is not an adequate model.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the link function linking the response probabilities to the linear predictors.

arguments.name: ALOGIT
arguments.description: Is the adjacent-category logit function. PROC LOGISTIC fits the adjacent-category logit model, in which each category is contrasted with the following category.

arguments.name: CLOGLOG
arguments.description: Complementary log-log function. PROC LOGISTIC fits the binary complementary log-log model when there are two response categories and fits the cumulative complementary log-log model when there are more than two response categories.

arguments.name: GLOGIT
arguments.description: Generalized logit function. PROC LOGISTIC fits the generalized logit model, in which each nonreference category is contrasted with the reference category. You can use the response variable option REF= to specify the reference category.

arguments.name: LOGIT
arguments.description: Log odds function. PROC LOGISTIC fits the binary logit model when there are two response categories and fits the cumulative logit model when there are more than two response categories.

arguments.name: PROBIT
arguments.description: Inverse standard normal distribution function. PROC LOGISTIC fits the binary probit model when there are two response categories and fits the cumulative probit model when there are more than two response categories.

arguments.name: MAXFUNCTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of function calls to perform when maximizing the conditional likelihood.

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations to perform. By default, MAXITER=25.

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of times any explanatory variable is added to or removed from the model when SELECTION=STEPWISE.

arguments.name: NOCHECK
arguments.description: Disables the checking process to determine whether maximum likelihood estimates of the regression parameters exist.

arguments.name: NODUMMYPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the "Class Level Information" table, which shows how the design matrix columns for the CLASS variables are coded.

arguments.name: NOFIT
arguments.description: Performs the global score test without fitting the model.

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept for the binary response model, the first intercept for the ordinal response model (which forces all intercepts to be nonnegative), or all intercepts for the generalized logit model.

arguments.name: NOLOGSCALE
arguments.description: Specifies that computations for the conditional and exact conditional logistic models should be computed by using normal scaling.

arguments.name: NOODDSRATIO
arguments.description: Suppresses the default "Odds Ratio" table.

arguments.name: OFFSET=
arguments.description: Names the offset variable.

arguments.name: ORPVALUE
arguments.description: Displays p-values in tables produced by the CLODDS= option and the ODDSRATIO statement. A p-value for an odds ratio corresponds to the significance level such that the two-sided confidence interval for the odds ratio has "1" as one of its endpoints. Computing profile-likelihood p-values requires optimizing restricted log-likelihood equations.

arguments.name: OUTROC=
arguments.description: Creates, for binary response models, an output SAS data set that contains the data necessary to produce the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve.

arguments.name: PARMLABEL
arguments.description: Displays the labels of the parameters in the "Analysis of Maximum Likelihood Estimates" table.

arguments.name: PCORR
arguments.description: Specifies to compute the partial correlation statistic for each model parameter (excluding the intercept).

arguments.name: PEVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies one prior probability or a list of prior probabilities for the event of interest.

arguments.name: PLCL
arguments.description: Is the same as specifying CLPARM=PL.

arguments.name: PLCONV=
arguments.description: Controls the convergence criterion for confidence intervals based on the profile-likelihood function. The quantity value must be a positive number, with a default value of 1E–4.

arguments.name: PLRL
arguments.description: Is the same as specifying CLODDS=PL.

arguments.name: PPROB=
arguments.description: Specifies one critical probability value (or cutpoint) or a list of critical probability values for classifying observations with the CTABLE option.

arguments.name: RIDGING=
arguments.description: Specifies the technique used to improve the log-likelihood function when its value in the current iteration is less than that in the previous iteration.

arguments.name: ABSOLUTE
arguments.description: The diagonal elements of the negative (expected) Hessian are inflated by adding the ridge value.

arguments.name: RELATIVE
arguments.description: The diagonal elements are inflated by a factor of 1 plus the ridge value. This is the default.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: The crude line search method of taking half a step is used instead of ridging.

arguments.name: RISKLIMITS
arguments.description: Is the same as specifying CLODDS=WALD.

arguments.name: ROCCI
arguments.description: Displays standard errors and confidence limits for the area under the ROC curve (AUC) statistic when you have a binary response variable. This option replaces the "Association of Predicted Probabilities and Observed Responses" table with the "ROC Association Statistics" table.

arguments.name: ROCEPS=
arguments.description: Specifies a criterion for the ROC curve used for grouping estimated event probabilities that are close to each other.

arguments.name: RSQUARE
arguments.description: Requests a generalized R² measure for the fitted model.

arguments.name: SCALE=
arguments.description: Enables you to supply the value of the dispersion parameter or to specify the method for estimating the dispersion parameter.

arguments.name: DEVIANCE
arguments.description: Specifies that the dispersion parameter be estimated by the deviance divided by its degrees of freedom.

arguments.name: PEARSON
arguments.description: Specifies that the dispersion parameter be estimated by the Pearson chi-square statistic divided by its degrees of freedom.

arguments.name: WILLIAMS
arguments.description: Specifies that Williams' method be used to model overdispersion. This option can be used only with the events/trials syntax. An optional constant can be specified as the scale parameter.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Specifies that no correction is needed for the dispersion parameter; that is, the dispersion parameter remains as 1.

arguments.name: <(constant)>
arguments.description: Sets the estimate of the dispersion parameter to be the square of the given constant.

arguments.name: SELECTION=
arguments.description: Specifies the method used to select the variables in the model.

arguments.name: BACKWARD
arguments.description: Requests backward elimination.

arguments.name: FORWARD
arguments.description: Requests forward selection.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Fits the complete model specified in the MODEL statement. This is the default.

arguments.name: STEPWISE
arguments.description: Requests stepwise selection.

arguments.name: SCORE
arguments.description: Requests best subset selection.

arguments.name: SEQUENTIAL
arguments.description: Forces effects to be added to the model in the order specified in the MODEL statement or eliminated from the model in the reverse order of that specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance for testing the singularity of the Hessian matrix (Newton-Raphson algorithm) or the expected value of the Hessian matrix (Fisher scoring algorithm).

arguments.name: SLENTRY=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level of the score chi-square for entering an effect into the model in the FORWARD or STEPWISE method.

arguments.name: SLSTAY=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level of the Wald chi-square for an effect to stay in the model in a backward elimination step.

arguments.name: START=
arguments.description: Specifies which effects in the MODEL statement are included in the initial model. You can specify the following values:

arguments.name: number
arguments.description: Requests that the first number effects be included in the initial model. The value of number ranges from 0 to s, where s is the total number of effects that are specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: EQUALSLOPES
arguments.description: Enables you to begin the model selection process with all the equal slope effects in the model.

arguments.name: STB
arguments.description: Displays the standardized estimates for the parameters for the continuous explanatory variables in the "Analysis of Maximum Likelihood Estimates" table.

arguments.name: STOP=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum (SELECTION=FORWARD) or minimum (SELECTION=BACKWARD) number of effects to be included in the final model.

arguments.name: STOPRES
arguments.description: Specifies that the removal or entry of effects be based on the value of the residual chi-square.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique for estimating the regression parameters.

arguments.name: FISHER
arguments.description: Fisher scoring algorithm

arguments.name: NEWTON
arguments.description: Newton-Raphson algorithm

arguments.name: UNEQUALSLOPES
arguments.description: Specifies one or more effects in a cumulative response model that have a different set of parameters for each response function. If you specify more than one effect, enclose the effects in parentheses. The effects must be explanatory effects that are specified in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: WALDCL
arguments.description: Is the same as specifying CLPARM=WALD.

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion.

statements.name: NLOPTIONS
statements.description: Most models fit with the GLIMMIX procedure typically have one or more nonlinear parameters. Estimation requires nonlinear optimization methods. You can control the optimization through options in the NLOPTIONS statement.

arguments.name: ABSCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ABSFCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute function difference convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ABSGCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ABSXCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the absolute parameter convergence criterion.

arguments.name: ASINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies an absolute singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

arguments.name: DAMPSTEP
arguments.description: Specifies that the initial step-size value aⁿ (where n=0) for each line search (used by the QUANEW, CONGRA, or NEWRAP technique) cannot be larger than r times the step-size value used in the former iteration.

arguments.name: FCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies a second function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative function convergence criterion.

arguments.name: FSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the FSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

arguments.name: GCONV2=
arguments.description: Specifies another relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: GCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative gradient convergence criterion.

arguments.name: HESCAL=
arguments.description: Specifies the scaling version of the Hessian or crossproduct Jacobian matrix used in NRRIDG, TRUREG, LEVMAR, NEWRAP, or DBLDOG optimization.
Specifies that no scaling is done.
Specifies the Moré (1978) scaling update
Specifies the Dennis, Gay, and Welsch (1981) scaling update
Specifies that di is reset in each iteration

arguments.name: INHESSIAN
arguments.description: Specifies how the initial estimate of the approximate Hessian is defined for the quasi-Newton techniques QUANEW and DBLDOG.

arguments.name: INSTEP=
arguments.description: Reduces the length of the first trial step during the line search of the first iterations.

arguments.name: LCDEACT=
arguments.description: Specifies a threshold r for the Lagrange multiplier that decides whether an active inequality constraint remains active or can be deactivated.

arguments.name: LCEPSILON=
arguments.description: Specifies the range r, r ≥ 0, for active and violated boundary and linear constraints.

arguments.name: LCSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a criterion r, r ≥ 0, used in the update of the QR decomposition that decides whether an active constraint is linearly dependent on a set of other active constraints.

arguments.name: LINESEARCH=
arguments.description: Specifies the line-search method for the CONGRA, QUANEW, and NEWRAP optimization techniques.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is similar to one used by the Harwell subroutine library.

Specifies a line-search method that needs more function calls than gradient calls for quadratic and cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.

Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for cubic interpolation and cubic extrapolation; this method is implemented as shown in Fletcher (1987) and can be modified to an exact line search by using the LSPRECISION= option.
Specifies a line-search method that needs the same number of function and gradient calls for stepwise extrapolation and cubic interpolation
Specifies a line-search method that is a modified version of LIS=4.
Specifies golden section line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies bisection line search (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.
Specifies Armijo line-search technique (Polak 1971), which uses only function values for linear approximation.

arguments.name: LSPRECISION=
arguments.description: Specifies the degree of accuracy that should be obtained by the line-search algorithms LIS=2 and LIS=3. The default LSPRECISION= values are:

arguments.name: MAXFUNC=
arguments.description: Requires the number of function calls to be no larger than i. The default values are:

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: Requires the number of iterations to be no larger than i. The default values are: o For TECH= LEVMAR, NEWRAP, NRRIDG, TRUREG: i=50 o For TECH= DBLDOG, QUANEW: i=200 o For TECH= CONGRA: i=400

arguments.name: MAXSTEP=
arguments.description: Specifies an upper bound for the step length of the line-search algorithms during the first n iterations.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: Requires the CPU time to be no larger than r. The default value of the MAXTIME= option is the largest double floating-point number on your computer.

arguments.name: MINITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the minimum number of iterations. The default value is 0.

arguments.name: MSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

arguments.name: NOPRINT
arguments.description: Suppresses output related to optimization such as the iteration history.

arguments.name: PALL
arguments.description: [Displays information about the starting values and final values of the optimization process.

arguments.name: PHISTORY
arguments.description: Displays the optimization history. The PHISTORY option is set automatically if the PALL or PRINT option is set.

arguments.name: RESTART=
arguments.description: Specifies that the QUANEW or CONGRA algorithm is restarted with a steepest descent/ascent search direction after at most i iterations, i > 0.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the singularity criterion r, 0 < r < 1, used, for example, for matrix inversion.

arguments.name: SOCKET=
arguments.description: Specifies the fileref that contains the information needed for remote monitoring.

arguments.name: TECHNIQUE=
arguments.description: Specifies the optimization technique.
arguments.help: TECHNIQUE=CONGRA | DBLDOG | LEVMAR | NEWRAP | NRRIDG | QUANEW | TRUREG | NONE

arguments.name: CONGRA
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different conjugate-gradient optimization algorithms, which can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: DBLDOG
arguments.description: Performs a version of double-dogleg optimization, which uses the gradient to update an approximation of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian.

arguments.name: LEVMAR
arguments.description: Performs a highly stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Levenberg-Marquardt optimization technique, a slightly improved variant of the Moré (1978) implementation. This is the default optimization technique if there are fewer than 40 parameters to estimate.

arguments.name: NEWRAP
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. The algorithm combines a line-search algorithm with ridging, and it can be modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: NRRIDG
arguments.description: Performs a usually stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming Newton-Raphson optimization technique. This algorithm does not perform a line search.

arguments.name: QUANEW
arguments.description: Chooses one of four different quasi-Newton optimization algorithms that can be more precisely defined with the UPDATE= option and modified with the LINESEARCH= option.

arguments.name: TRUREG
arguments.description: Performs a usually very stable but, for large problems, memory- and time-consuming trust-region optimization technique. The algorithm is implemented similar to Gay (1983) and Moré and Sorensen (1983).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Does not perform any optimization. This option is similar to METHOD=NONE, but TECH=NONE also computes and displays residuals and goodness of fit statistics.

arguments.name: UPDATE=
arguments.description: Specifies the update method for the quasi-Newton, double-dogleg, or conjugate-gradient optimization technique.
arguments.help: UPDATE=BFGS | DBFGS | DDFP | DFP | PB | FR | PR | CD

arguments.name: BFGS
arguments.description: Performs the original Broyden, Fletcher, Goldfarb, and Shanno (BFGS) update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DBFGS
arguments.description: Performs the dual BFGS update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix. This is the default update method.

arguments.name: DDFP
arguments.description: Performs the dual Davidon, Fletcher, and Powell (DFP) update of the Cholesky factor of the Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: DFP
arguments.description: Performs the original DFP update of the inverse Hessian matrix.

arguments.name: PB
arguments.description: Performs the automatic restart update method of Powell (1977) and Beale (1972).

arguments.name: FR
arguments.description: Performs the Fletcher-Reeves update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: PR
arguments.description: Performs the Polak-Ribiere update (Fletcher 1987).

arguments.name: CD
arguments.description: Performs a conjugate-descent update of Fletcher (1987).

arguments.name: VERSION=
arguments.description: Specifies the version of the quasi-Newton optimization technique with nonlinear constraints.
Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1978a, 1978b) (update like VF02AD).
Specifies the update of the U vector as in Powell (1982a, 1982b) (update like VMCWD).

arguments.name: VSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies a relative singularity criterion r, r > 0, for the inversion of the information matrix, which is needed to compute the covariance matrix.

arguments.name: XCONV=
arguments.description: Specifies the relative parameter convergence criterion. Termination requires a small relative parameter change in subsequent iterations.

arguments.name: XSIZE=
arguments.description: Specifies the XSIZE parameter of the relative function and relative gradient termination criteria. The default value is r=0.

statements.name: ODDSRATIO
statements.description: The ODDSRATIO statement produces odds ratios for variable even when the variable is involved in interactions with other covariates, and for classification variables that use any parameterization. You can also specify variables on which constructed effects are based, in addition to the names of COLLECTION or MULTIMEMBER effects. You can specify several ODDSRATIO statements.
statements.help: ODDSRATIO <AT(covariate=value-list | REF | ALL<...covariate=value-list | REF | ALL>)> <CL=<WALD | PL | BOTH>> <DIFF=<REF | ALL>> ...

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Specifies fixed levels of the interacting covariates. If a specified covariate does not interact with the variable, then its AT list is ignored.

arguments.name: CL=
arguments.description: Specifies whether to create Wald or profile-likelihood confidence limits, or both. By default, Wald confidence limits are produced.

arguments.name: WALD
arguments.description: Specifies to create Wald confidence limits.

arguments.name: PL
arguments.description: Specifies to create profile-likelihood confidence limits.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: Specifies to create both Wald and profile-likelihood confidence limits.

arguments.name: DIFF=
arguments.description: Specifies whether the odds ratios for a classification variable are computed against the reference level, or all pairs of variable are compared.

arguments.name: REF
arguments.description: Specifies that the odds ratios for a classification variable are computed against the reference level.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Specifies that the odds ratios for a classification variable are computed against all pairs of variable.

arguments.name: PLCONV=
arguments.description: Controls the convergence criterion for confidence intervals based on the profile-likelihood function. The quantity value must be a positive number, with a default value of 1E–4. The PLCONV= option has no effect if profile- likelihood confidence intervals (CL=PL) are not requested.

arguments.name: PLMAXITER=
arguments.description: Specifies the maximum number of iterations to perform. By default, PLMAXITER=25. If convergence is not attained in n iterations, the odds ratio or the confidence limits are set to missing. The PLMAXITER= option has no effect if profile-likelihood confidence intervals (CL=PL) are not requested.

arguments.name: PLSINGULAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the tolerance for testing the singularity of the Hessian matrix (Newton-Raphson algorithm) or the expected value of the Hessian matrix (Fisher scoring algorithm). The test requires that a pivot for sweeping this matrix be at least this number times a norm of the matrix. Values of the PLSINGULAR= option must be numeric. By default, value is the machine epsilon times 1E7, which is approximately 1E–9. The PLSINGULAR= option has no effect if profile-likelihood confidence intervals (CL=PL) are not requested.

statements.name: OUTPUT
statements.description: The OUTPUT statement creates a new SAS data set that contains all the variables in the input data set and, optionally, the estimated linear predictors and their standard error estimates, the estimates of the cumulative or individual response probabilities, and the confidence limits for the cumulative probabilities.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the output data set. If you omit the OUT= option, the output data set is created and given a default name by using the DATAn convention.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Sets the level of significance α for 100(1 - α)% confidence limits for the appropriate response probabilities. The value of number must be between 0 and 1.

arguments.name: C=
arguments.description: Specifies the confidence interval displacement diagnostic that measures the influence of individual observations on the regression estimates.

arguments.name: CBAR=
arguments.description: Specifies the confidence interval displacement diagnostic that measures the overall change in the global regression estimates due to deleting an individual observation.

arguments.name: DFBETAS=
arguments.description: Specifies the standardized differences in the regression estimates for assessing the effects of individual observations on the estimated regression parameters in the fitted model.

arguments.name: _ALL_
arguments.description: The DFBETAS statistics are named DFBETA_xxx, where xxx is the name of the regression parameter.

arguments.name: var-list
arguments.description: You can specify a list of up to s + 1 variable names, where s is the number of explanatory variables in the MODEL statement.

arguments.name: DIFCHISQ=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in the chi-square goodness-of-fit statistic attributable to deleting the individual observation.

arguments.name: DIFDEV=
arguments.description: Specifies the change in the deviance attributable to deleting the individual observation.

arguments.name: H=
arguments.description: Specifies the diagonal element of the hat matrix for detecting extreme points in the design space.

arguments.name: LOWER=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the lower confidence limits for π, where π is the probability of the event response if events/trials syntax or single-trial syntax with binary response is specified.

arguments.name: PREDICTED=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the predicted probabilities.

arguments.name: PREDPROBS=
arguments.description: Requests individual, cumulative, or cross validated predicted probabilities.
arguments.help: PREDPROBS=(INDIVIDUAL CUMULATIVE) | (INDIVIDUAL CROSSVALIDATE) | (CUMULATIVE CROSSVALIDATE) | (INDIVIDUAL CUMULATIVE CROSSVALIDATE)

arguments.name: (INDIVIDUAL CUMULATIVE)
arguments.description: Requests the predicted probability and cumulative predicted probability of each response level.

arguments.name: (INDIVIDUAL CROSSVALIDATE)
arguments.description: Requests the predicted probability and cross validated individual predicted probability of each response level.

arguments.name: (CUMULATIVE CROSSVALIDATE)
arguments.description: Requests the cumulative predicted probability and cross validated individual predicted probability of each response level.

arguments.name: (INDIVIDUAL CUMULATIVE CROSSVALIDATE)
arguments.description: Requests the predicted probability, cumulative predicted probability, and cross validated individual predicted probability of each response level.

arguments.name: RESCHI=
arguments.description: Specifies the Pearson (chi-square) residual for identifying observations that are poorly accounted for by the model.

arguments.name: RESDEV=
arguments.description: Specifies the deviance residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: RESLIK=
arguments.description: Specifies the likelihood residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: STDRESCHI=
arguments.description: Specifies the standardized Pearson (chi-square) residual for identifying observations that are poorly accounted for by the model.

arguments.name: STDRESDEV=
arguments.description: Specifies the standardized deviance residual for identifying poorly fitted observations.

arguments.name: STDXBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the standard error estimates of XBETA.

arguments.name: UPPER=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the upper confidence limits for π, where π is the probability of the event response if events/trials syntax or single-trial syntax with binary response is specified.

arguments.name: XBETA=
arguments.description: Names the variable containing the estimates of the linear predictor αi + β'x, where i is the corresponding ordered value of _LEVEL_.

statements.name: ROC
statements.description: The ROC statements specify models to be used in the ROC comparisons. You can specify more than one ROC statement. ROC statements are identified by their label—if you do not specify a label, the ith ROC statement is labeled "ROCi". Additionally, the specified or selected model is labeled with the MODEL statement label or "Model" if the MODEL label is not present. The specification can be either a list of effects that have previously been specified in the MODEL statement, or PRED=variable, where the variable does not have to be specified in the MODEL statement. The PRED= option allows you to input a criterion produced outside PROC LOGISTIC; for example, you can fit a random-intercept model by using PROC GLIMMIX or use survey weights in PROC SURVEYLOGISTIC, then use the predicted values from those models to produce an ROC curve for the comparisons. If you do not make a specification, then an intercept-only model is fit to the data, resulting in a noninformative ROC curve that can be used for comparing the area under another ROC curve to 0.5.

arguments.name: LINK=
arguments.description: Specifies the link function to be used in the model.

arguments.name: LOGIT
arguments.description: Log odds function

arguments.name: NORMIT
arguments.description: Inverse standard normal probability integral function

arguments.name: CLOGLOG
arguments.description: Complementary log-log function

arguments.name: NOINT
arguments.description: Suppresses the intercept for the model. Note that specifying the NOINT option in the MODEL statement does not affect the ROC model.

arguments.name: NOOFFSET
arguments.description: Does not include an offset variable if the OFFSET= option is specified in the MODEL statement.

statements.name: ROCCONTRAST
statements.description: The ROCCONTRAST statement compares the different ROC models.

arguments.name: ADJACENTPAIRS
arguments.description: Produces a contrast matrix of each ROC curve minus the succeeding curve.

arguments.name: REFERENCE=
arguments.description: Produces a contrast matrix of differences between each ROC curve and a reference curve.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays covariance matrices used in the computations.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Displays the contrast.

arguments.name: ESTIMATE=
arguments.description: Produces estimates of each row of the contrast, or estimates of every pairwise difference of ROC curves.

arguments.name: ROWS
arguments.description: Produces estimates of each row of the contrast. Same effect as spefifying ESTIMATE.

arguments.name: ALLPAIRS
arguments.description: Produces estimates of every pairwise difference of ROC curves.

statements.name: SCORE
statements.description: The SCORE statement creates a data set that contains all the data in the DATA= data set together with posterior probabilities and, optionally, prediction confidence intervals.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Specifies the significance level α for 100(1 - α)% confidence intervals.

arguments.name: CLM
arguments.description: Outputs the Wald-test-based confidence limits for the predicted probabilities.

arguments.name: CUMULATIVE
arguments.description: Outputs the cumulative predicted probabilities Pr(Y ≤ i), i = 1,...k+1, to the OUT= data set.

arguments.name: DATA=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that you want to score.

arguments.name: FITSTAT
arguments.description: Displays fit statistics for the data set you are scoring. The data set must contain the response variable.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the predicted information.

arguments.name: OUTROC=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the ROC curve for the DATA= data set.

arguments.name: PRIOR=
arguments.description: Names the SAS data set that contains the priors of the response categories.

arguments.name: PRIOREVENT=
arguments.description: Specifies the prior event probability for a binary response model.

arguments.name: ROCEPS=
arguments.description: Specifies the criterion for grouping estimated event probabilities that are close to each other for the ROC curve.

statements.name: SLICE
statements.description: The SLICE statement provides a general mechanism for performing a partitioned analysis of the LS-means for an interaction. This analysis is also known as an analysis of simple effects. The SLICE statement uses the same options as the LSMEANS statement.

arguments.name: ADJDFE=
arguments.description: Specifies how denominator degrees of freedom are determined when p-values and confidence limits are adjusted for multiple comparisons with the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: SOURCE
arguments.description: The denominator degrees of freedom for multiplicity-adjusted results are the denominator degrees of freedom for the LS-mean effect in the "Type III Tests of Fixed Effects" table.

arguments.name: ROW
arguments.description: Useful if you want multiplicity adjustments to take into account that denominator degrees of freedom are not constant across LS-mean differences.

arguments.name: ADJUST=
arguments.description: Requests a multiple comparison adjustment for the p-values and confidence limits for the differences of LS-means.
arguments.help: ADJUST=BON | DUNNETT | NELSON | SCHEFFE | SIDAK | SIMULATE | SMM | TUKEY

arguments.name: BON
arguments.description: Bonferroni adjustment

arguments.name: DUNNETT
arguments.description: Dunnett adjustment (in which the procedure analyzes all differences with a control level)

arguments.name: NELSON
arguments.description: Nelson adjustment (in which ANOM differences are taken)

arguments.name: SCHEFFE
arguments.description: Scheffe's adjustment

arguments.name: SIDAK
arguments.description: Sidak adjustment

arguments.name: SIMULATE
arguments.description: Computes adjusted p-values and confidence limits from the simulated distribution of the maximum or maximum absolute value of a multivariate t random vector. Syntax: SIMULATE<(simoptions)> You can specify the following simoptions in parentheses after the ADJUST=SIMULATE option. ACC=value specifies the target accuracy radius γ of a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. EPS=value specifies the value ε for a 100(1-ε)% confidence interval for the true probability content of the estimated (1-α)th quantile. The default value is ACC=0.005. NSAMP=n specifies the sample size for the simulation. SEED=number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random number generator for the simulation. THREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be divided into parallel threads, where the number of threads is the value of the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=. NOTHREADS specifies that the computational work for the simulation be performed in sequence rather than in parallel. NOTHREADS is the default. This option overrides the SAS system option THREADS|NOTHREADS.

arguments.name: SMM
arguments.description: SMM adjustment

arguments.name: TUKEY
arguments.description: If your data are unbalanced, PROC GLIMMIX uses the approximation described in Kramer (1956) and identifies the adjustment as "Tukey-Kramer" in the results.

arguments.name: ALPHA=
arguments.description: Requests that a t-type confidence interval be constructed for each of the LS-means with confidence level (1-number)x100%. The value of number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 0.05.

arguments.name: AT=
arguments.description: Modifies the values of the covariates that are used in computing LS-means. By default, all covariate effects are set equal to their mean values for computation of standard LS-means. The AT option enables you to assign arbitrary values to the covariates. Additional columns in the output table indicate the values of the covariates.

arguments.name: BYLEVEL
arguments.description: Requests that separate margins be computed for each level of the SLICE model-effect.

arguments.name: CL
arguments.description: Requests that t-type confidence limits be constructed for each of the LS-means. The confidence level is 0.95 by default; this can be changed with the ALPHA= option.

arguments.name: CORR
arguments.description: Displays the estimated correlation matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: COV
arguments.description: Displays the estimated covariance matrix of the least squares means as part of the "Least Squares Means" table.

arguments.name: DF=
arguments.description: Specifies the degrees of freedom for the t test and confidence limits. The default is the denominator degrees of freedom taken from the "Type III Tests" table that corresponds to the LS-means effect.

arguments.name: DIFF=
arguments.description: Requests that differences of the LS-means be displayed.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests all pairwise differences; this is the default.

arguments.name: ANOM
arguments.description: Requests differences between each LS-mean and the average LS-mean, as in the analysis of means (Ott 1967).

arguments.name: CONTROL
arguments.description: Requests the differences with a control, which, by default, is the first level of each of the specified SLICE effects.

arguments.name: CONTROLL
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly smaller than the control; the upper confidence limits for the control minus the noncontrol levels are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: CONTROLU
arguments.description: Tests whether the noncontrol levels are significantly larger than the control; the upper confidence limits for the noncontrol levels minus the control are considered to be infinity and are displayed as missing.

arguments.name: E
arguments.description: Requests that the L matrix coefficients for the SLICE effects be displayed.

arguments.name: EXP
arguments.description: Requests exponentiation of the LS-means or LS-mean differences. When you model data with the logit, cumulative logit, or generalized logit link functions, and the estimate represents a log odds ratio or log cumulative odds ratio, the EXP option produces an odds ratio. In proportional hazards model, the exponentiation of the LS-mean differences produces estimates of hazard ratios. If you specify the CL or ALPHA= option, the (adjusted) confidence bounds are also exponentiated.

arguments.name: ILINK
arguments.description: Requests that estimates and their standard errors in the "Least Squares Means" table also be reported on the scale of the mean (the inverse linked scale).

arguments.name: LINES
arguments.description: Presents results of comparisons between all pairs of least squares means by listing the means in descending order and indicating nonsignificant subsets by line segments beside the corresponding LS-means.

arguments.name: MEANS
arguments.description: Specifies to produce the table of least squares means.

arguments.name: NOF
arguments.description: Suppresses the F test for testing the mutual equality of the estimable functions in the partition.

arguments.name: NOMEANS
arguments.description: Specifies not to produce the table of least squares means. This is the default.

arguments.name: OBSMARGINS=
arguments.description: Specifies a potentially different weighting scheme for the computation of LS-means coefficients. The standard LS-means have equal coefficients across classification effects; however, the OM option changes these coefficients to be proportional to those found in the OM-data-set. This adjustment is reasonable when you want your inferences to apply to a population that is not necessarily balanced but has the margins that are observed in OM-data-set.

arguments.name: ODDSRATIO
arguments.description: Requests that LS-mean differences (DIFF, ADJUST= options) are also reported in terms of odds ratios. The ODDSRATIO option is ignored unless you use either the logit, cumulative logit, or generalized logit link function. If you specify the CL or ALPHA= option, confidence intervals for the odds ratios are also computed. These intervals are adjusted for multiplicity when you specify the ADJUST= option.

arguments.name: PDIFF
arguments.description: Is the same as the DIFF option.

arguments.name: PLOT=
arguments.description: Requests that least squares means related graphics are produced via ODS Graphics, provided that the ODS GRAPHICS statement has been specified and the plot request does not conflict with other options in the SLICE statement.
arguments.help: PLOT=ALL | ANOMPLOT | BOXPLOT | CONTROLPLOT | DIFFPLOT | DISTPLOT | MEANPLOT | NONE

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Requests that the default plots corresponding to this SLICE statement be produced.

arguments.name: ANOMPLOT
arguments.description: Requests an analysis of means display in which least squares means are compared to an average least squares mean.

arguments.name: BOXPLOT
arguments.description: Produces box plots of the distribution of the least squares mean or least squares mean differences across a posterior sample. For example, this plot is available in procedures that support a Bayesian analysis through the BAYES statement. A separate box is generated for each estimable function, and all boxes appear on a single graph by default. You can affect the appearance of the box plot graph with the following options: ORIENTATION=VERTICAL|HORIZONTAL ORIENT=VERT|HORIZ specifies the orientation of the boxes. The default is vertical orientation of the box plots. NPANELPOS=number specifies how to break the series of box plots across multiple panels. If the NPANELPOS option is not specified, or if number equals zero, then all box plots are displayed in a single graph; this is the default.

arguments.name: CONTROLPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display in which least squares means are visually compared against a reference level.

arguments.name: DIFFPLOT
arguments.description: Requests a display of all pairwise least squares mean differences and their significance. Syntax: DIFFPLOT<(diffplot-options)> You can specify the following diffplot-options: ABS all line segments are shown on the same side of the reference line. NOABS separates comparisons according to the sign of the difference. CENTER marks the center point for each comparison. NOLINES suppresses the display of the line segments that represent the confidence bounds for the differences of the least squares means. The NOLINES option implies the CENTER option.

arguments.name: DISTPLOT
arguments.description: enerates panels of histograms with a kernel density overlaid if the analysis has access to a set of posterior parameter estimates. You can sepcify the following distplot-options in parentheses: BOX|NOBOX controls the display of a horizontal box plot of the estimable function's distribution across the posterior sample below the graph. The BOX option is enabled by default. HIST|NOHIST controls the display of the histogram of the estimable function's distribution across the posterior sample. The HIST option is enabled by default. NORMAL|NONORMAL controls the display of a normal density estimate on the graph. The NONORMAL option is enabled by default. KERNEL|NOKERNEL controls the display of a kernel density estimate on the graph. The KERNEL option is enabled by default. NROWS=number specifies the highest number of rows in a panel. The default is 3. NCOLS=number specifies the highest number of columns in a panel. The default is 3. UNPACK unpacks the panel into separate graphics.

arguments.name: MEANPLOT
arguments.description: Syntax: MEANPLOT<(meanplot-options)> Requests displays of the least squares means. The following meanplot-options control the display of the least squares means: ASCENDING displays the least squares means in ascending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. CL displays upper and lower confidence limits for the least squares means. By default, 95% limits are drawn. CLBAND displays confidence limits as bands. This option implies the JOIN option. DESCENDING displays the least squares means in descending order. This option has no effect if means are sliced or displayed in separate plots. ILINK requests that means (and confidence limits) are displayed on the inverse linked scale. JOIN | CONNECT connects the least squares means with lines. This option is implied by the CLBAND option. SLICEBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to group the means in a single plot. PLOTBY=fixed-effect specifies an effect by which to break interaction plots into separate displays.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Requests that no plots be produced.

arguments.name: SEED=
arguments.description: Specifies the seed for the sampling-based components of the computations for the SLICE statement (for example, chi-bar-square statistics and simulated p-values). number specifies an integer that is used to start the pseudo-random-number generator for the simulation. If you do not specify a seed, or if you specify a value less than or equal to zero, the seed is generated from reading the time of day from the computer clock.

arguments.name: SINGULAR=
arguments.description: Tunes the estimability checking. The value for number must be between 0 and 1; the default is 1E-4.

arguments.name: STEPDOWN=
arguments.description: Requests that multiple comparison adjustments for the p-values of LS-mean differences be further adjusted in a step-down fashion. Step-down methods increase the power of multiple comparisons by taking advantage of the fact that a p-value is never declared significant unless all smaller p-values are also declared significant. You can specify the following step-down options in parentheses: MAXTIME=n specifies the time (in seconds) to spend computing the maximal logically consistent sequential subsets of equality hypotheses for TYPE=LOGICAL. REPORT specifies that a report on the step-down adjustment should be displayed, including a listing of the sequential subsets (Westfall 1997) and, for ADJUST=SIMULATE, the step-down simulation results.

statements.name: STORE
statements.description: The STORE statement requests that the procedure save the context and results of the statistical analysis. The resulting item store is a binary file format that cannot be modified. The contents of the item store can be processed with the PLM procedure. The item-store-name is a usual one- or two-level SAS name, like the names that are used for SAS data sets. If you specify a one-level name, then the item store resides in the WORK library and is deleted at the end of the SAS session. Since item stores usually are used to perform postprocessing tasks, typical usage specifies a two-level name of the form libname.membername. If an item store by the same name as specified in the STORE statement already exists, the existing store is replaced.

arguments.name: LABEL=
arguments.description: Adds a custom label. When the PLM procedure processes an item store, the label appears in the PROC PLM output along with other identifying information.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: The item-store-name is a usual one- or two-level SAS name, like the names that are used for SAS data sets. If you specify a one-level name, then the item store resides in the WORK library and is deleted at the end of the SAS session.

statements.name: STRATA
statements.description: The STRATA statement names the variables that define strata or matched sets to use in a stratified conditional logistic regression of binary response data.

arguments.name: CHECKDEPENDENCY=
arguments.description: Specifies which variables are to be tested for dependency before the analysis is performed.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: Performs no dependence checking.

arguments.name: COVARIATES
arguments.description: Checks dependence between covariates and an added intercept.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: Checks dependence between all the strata and covariates

arguments.name: INFO
arguments.description: Displays the "Strata Information" table, which includes the stratum number, levels of the STRATA variables that define the stratum, the number of events, the number of nonevents, and the total frequency for each stratum.

arguments.name: MISSING
arguments.description: Treats missing values ('.','.A',...,'.Z' for numeric variables and blanks for character variables) as valid STRATA variable values.

arguments.name: NOSUMMARY
arguments.description: Suppresses the display of the "Strata Summary" table.

statements.name: TEST
statements.description: The TEST statement tests linear hypotheses about the regression coefficients.

arguments.name: PRINT
arguments.description: Displays intermediate calculations in the testing of the null hypothesis.

statements.name: UNITS
statements.description: The UNITS statement enables you to specify units of change for the continuous explanatory variables so that customized odds ratios can be estimated.

arguments.name: DEFAULT=
arguments.description: Gives a list of units of change for all explanatory variables that are not specified in the UNITS statement.

statements.name: WEIGHT
statements.description: When a WEIGHT statement appears, each observation in the input data set is weighted by the value of the WEIGHT variable.

arguments.name: NORMALIZE
arguments.description: Causes the weights specified by the WEIGHT variable to be normalized so that they add up to the actual sample size.
